questions.ocrQuestion:
The repulsive force between the positively charged protons does not throw then apart, because
(a) nuclear force is stronger
(b) neutrons exist between protons
(c) coulombian force does not act at small distances
(d) due to reasons other the mentioned above
questions.onlyq_text: The repulsive force between the positively charged protons does not throw then apart, because

options.option: (c) coulombian force does not act at small distances
(d) due to reasons other the mentioned above

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Some radioactive nucleus may emit
a. Only one \( \alpha, \beta \) or \( \gamma \) at a time
b. All the three \( \alpha, \beta \) and \( \gamma \) one after another
c. All the three \( \alpha, \beta \) and \( \gamma \) simultaneously
d. Only \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \) simultaneously
questions.onlyq_text: Some radioactive nucleus may emit

options.option: a. Only one \( \alpha, \beta \) or \( \gamma \) at a time
b. All the three \( \alpha, \beta \) and \( \gamma \) one after another

questions.sol_html: (a) No radioactive substance emit both \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \) particles simultaneously. Some substances emit \( \alpha \)-particles and some other emits \( \beta \)-particles. \( \gamma \) - rays are emitted along with both \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \)-particles.

questions.ocrQuestion:
What percentage of original radioactive atoms is left after five half lives
a. \( 0.3 \% \)
b. \( 1 \% \)
c. \( 31 \% \)
d. \( 3.125 \% \)
questions.onlyq_text: What percentage of original radioactive atoms is left after five half lives
questions.sol_html: (d) Fraction of atoms remains after five half lives\[\frac{N}{N_{0}}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{t / T}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{5 T / T}=\frac{1}{32}\]Percentage atom remains\[=\frac{1}{32} \times 100=3.125 \%\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( T \) is the half life of a radioactive material, then the fraction that would remain after a time \( \frac{T}{2} \) is
a. \( \frac{1}{2} \)
b. \( \frac{3}{4} \)
c. \( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \)
d. \( \frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{\sqrt{2}} \)
questions.onlyq_text: If \( T \) is the half life of a radioactive material, then the fraction that would remain after a time \( \frac{T}{2} \) is
questions.sol_html: (c) Fraction remains after \( n \) half lives\[\begin{array}{l}\frac{N}{N_{0}}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{t / T} \\\frac{N}{N_{0}}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{T / 2}{T}}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{1 / 2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{array}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

b. \( \frac{\log _{e} 2}{\lambda} \) and \( \frac{1}{\lambda} \)
c. \( \lambda \log _{e} 2 \) and \( \frac{1}{\lambda} \)
d. \( \frac{\lambda}{\log _{e} 2} \) and \( \frac{1}{\lambda} \)

questions.ocrQuestion:
Which of the following is in the increasing order for penetrating power
a. \( \alpha, \beta, \gamma \)
b. \( \beta, \alpha, \gamma \)
c. \( \gamma, \alpha, \beta \)
d. \( \gamma, \beta, \alpha \)
questions.onlyq_text: Which of the following is in the increasing order for penetrating power
questions.sol_html: (a) Penetration power of \( \gamma \) is 100 times of \( \beta \), while that of \( \beta \) is 100 times of \( \alpha \).
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The half-life of \( B i^{210} \) is 5 days. What time is taken by \( (7 / 8)^{\text {th }} \) part of the sample to decay
a. 3.4 days
b. 10 days
c. 15 days
d. 20 days
questions.onlyq_text: The half-life of \( B i^{210} \) is 5 days. What time is taken by \( (7 / 8)^{\text {th }} \) part of the sample to decay
questions.sol_html: (c) By using \( N=N_{0}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{t / T} \); where \( N=\left(1-\frac{7}{8}\right) N_{0}=\frac{1}{8} N_{0} \)\[\begin{array}{l}\frac{1}{8} N_{0}=N_{0}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{t / T} \\\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{3}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{t / 5} \Rightarrow t=15 \text { days. }\end{array}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Consider a radioactive material of half-life 1.0 minute. If one of the nuclei decays now, the next one will decay
a. After 1 minute
b. After \( \frac{1}{\log _{e} 2} \) minute
c. After \( \frac{1}{N} \) minute, where \( \mathrm{N} \) is the number of nuclei present at that moment
d. After any time
questions.onlyq_text: Consider a radioactive material of half-life 1.0 minute. If one of the nuclei decays now, the next one will decay

options.option: c. After \( \frac{1}{N} \) minute, where \( \mathrm{N} \) is the number of nuclei present at that moment

questions.sol_html: (d) Because radioactivity is a spontaneous phenomenon.
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The half life \( (\mathrm{T}) \) and the disintegration constant \( (\lambda) \) of a radioactive substance are related as
a. \( \lambda T=1 \)
b. \( \lambda T=0.693 \)
c. \( \frac{T}{\lambda}=0.693 \)
d. \( \frac{\lambda}{T}=0.693 \)
questions.onlyq_text: The half life \( (\mathrm{T}) \) and the disintegration constant \( (\lambda) \) of a radioactive substance are related as
questions.sol_html: 20. (b) By using \( N=N_{0} e^{-\lambda t} \)\[\begin{array}{l}\Rightarrow \quad \frac{N_{0}}{2}=N_{0} e^{-\lambda T_{1 / 2}} \\\Rightarrow \quad 2=e^{\lambda T_{1 / 2}}\end{array}\]By taking \( \log _{e} \) both the side \( \log _{e} 2=\lambda T_{1 / 2} \)\[\Rightarrow \quad \lambda T_{1 / 2}=0.693\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The half life period of a radioactive substance is \( 5 \mathrm{~min} \). The amount of substance decayed in \( 20 \mathrm{~min} \) will be
a. \( 93.75 \% \)
b. \( 75 \% \)
c. \( 25 \% \)
d. \( 6.25 \% \)
questions.onlyq_text: The half life period of a radioactive substance is \( 5 \mathrm{~min} \). The amount of substance decayed in \( 20 \mathrm{~min} \) will be
questions.sol_html: (a) Number of half lives in \( 20 \mathrm{~min}=n=\frac{20}{5}=4 \)Fraction of material remains after four half lives \( =\frac{1}{16} \)Hence fraction that decays\[=1-\frac{1}{16}=\frac{15}{16}=93.75 \%\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Radon \( (R a) \) decays into Polonium \( \left(P_{0}\right) \) by emitting an \( \alpha \)-particle with half-life of 4 days. A sample contains \( 6.4 \times 10^{10} \) atoms of \( R n \). After 12 days, the number of atoms of \( R_{n} \) left in the sample will be
a. \( 3.2 \times 10^{10} \)
b. \( 0.53 \times 10^{10} \)
c. \( 2.1 \times 10^{10} \)
d. \( 0.8 \times 10^{10} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Radon \( (R a) \) decays into Polonium \( \left(P_{0}\right) \) by emitting an \( \alpha \)-particle with half-life of 4 days. A sample contains \( 6.4 \times 10^{10} \) atoms of \( R n \). After 12 days, the number of atoms of \( R_{n} \) left in the sample will be
questions.sol_html: (d) In the given case, 12 days \( =3 \) half lives Number of atoms left after 3 half lives.\[=6.4 \times 10^{10} \times \frac{1}{2^{3}}=0.8 \times 10^{10}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS
